NEW DELHI: China has not accepted India's proposal to carry out bilateral trade in local currencies which was aimed at bridging the ballooning trade deficit with the neighbouring country, an official said.India's exports to China stood at only $13.4 billion, imports aggregated to $76.4 billion in 2017-18, leaving a trade deficit of $63 billion. It was $51.11 billion in 2016-17.India had suggested China for renminbi-rupee trade to boost its exports and tackle the widening trade deficit concern."They have not accepted the proposal," the official said.The issue was discussed in an inter-ministerial meeting in October. In the meeting, it was suggested to the Reserve Bank of India and the Department of Economic Affairs would look at the possibility of exploring renminbi-rupee trade with China.
  


India has also proposed trade in national currencies with some other countries, including Russia, Iran and Venezuela. New Delhi has trade deficit with these three countries, too.The Federation of Indian Export Organisations (FIEO) President Ganesh Kumar Gupta said that the government should promote exports from India in the domestic currency."This will help in bridging trade deficit with countries like China," Gupta said.Trade experts have stated that bilateral trade in domestic currencies will help India only in the case of those countries with which it has a trade balance."Trade imbalance should not be there with the country with which we want to do trade in rupee. It will not help in bridging the deficit. The partner country should have an opportunity to invest in India to use the rupee," said Biswajit Dhar, professor at Jawaharlal Nehru University.The Indian industry and exporters have time and again raised the issue of increasing trade deficit with China and have asked the government to seek greater market access for domestic goods in the Chinese market.Recently, China has permitted exports of rice and sugar. But India wants to increase exports of several other items, including pharmaceuticals, engineering and services.
data.description: India had suggested China for renminbi-rupee trade to boost its exports and tackle the widening trade deficit concern.

66882767.headline: India's September quarter GDP growth moderates to 7.1%, lower than estimates
66882767.summary: The data comes days after a joint exercise of CSO and NITI Aayog revised downwards the GDP growth for the UPA years between 2005-06 and 2011-12 based on the new base year 2011-12.

data.headline: India's September quarter GDP growth moderates to 7.1%, lower than estimates
data.articleBody: New Delhi: India's economy grew at 7.1 per cent for the second quarter of the current fiscal losing the momentum sequentially from the first quarter when it grew at a nine-quarter high of 8.2 per cent on the back of increase in investment and consumption demand in the economy.A Reuters poll had forecast that the economic growth had likely moderated to 7.4 per cent in the July-September period.The GVA growth for Q2 came in at 6.9 per cent. The manufacturing output grew at a robust 7.4 per cent on the back of a stronger industrial output.  The data, released by the Central Statistics Office, comes days after a joint exercise of CSO and NITI Aayog revised downwards the GDP growth for the UPA years between 2005-06 and 2011-12 based on the new base year 2011-12.The Narendra Modi-led NDA government is preparing to go into general elections next year on the back of a stronger economic growth compared to the UPA era.The first quarter GDP growth was mainly driven by robust growth in gross fixed capital formation (GFCF) as it expanded by double digits for the second consecutive quarter (Q4FY18 and Q1FY19) and a pick up in demand in the rural sector.The RBI, in its last monetary policy framework, had projected the GDP growth for 2018-19 at 7.4 per cent (7.4 per cent in Q2 and 7.1-7.3 per cent in H2).The second half could see moderation in economic growth on the back of a liquidity crisis and a likely credit crunch triggered by the crisis in India's shadow banking sector. The economy could see support from the RBI's likely move to hold back any further hike in interest rates as the inflation is expected to remain within its comfort zone on the back of a sharp decline in international crude oil prices.
data.description: The data comes days after a joint exercise of CSO and NITI Aayog revised downwards the GDP growth for the UPA years between 2005-06 and 2011-12 based on the new base year 2011-12.

66882658.headline: Core sector growth improves to 4.8% in October
66882658.summary: India’s infrastructure sector growth slowed to 4.2 per cent in August hit by a decline in crude oil and fertiliser production and sluggish performance of coal, steel, refinery products and natural gas sectors.

data.headline: Core sector growth improves to 4.8% in October
data.articleBody: The announcement of incentives worth Rs 8,450 crore by the government will not only boost exports of goods and services, but also increase employment generation and value-addition. New Delhi: Growth of eight infrastructure sectors improved sequentially to 4.8 per cent in October on the back of strong cement, coal and crude oil output. India’s infrastructure sector growth slowed to 4.3 per cent in September hit by a decline in crude oil and fertiliser production and sluggish performance of coal, steel, refinery products and natural gas sectors.Eight Core Industries are Electricity , steel, refinery products, crude oil, coal, cement, natural gas and fertilizers. The Index of Eight Core Industries is a monthly production index, which is also considered as a lead indicator of the monthly industrial performance.The cumulative growth in the combined index of eight core industries during April-August, 2018-19 was 5.5 per cent.
data.description: India’s infrastructure sector growth slowed to 4.2 per cent in August hit by a decline in crude oil and fertiliser production and sluggish performance of coal, steel, refinery products and natural gas sectors.

66879192.headline: Indian economy likely to grow at 7-7.4 per cent in FY19: NCAER
66879192.summary: The current account balance and central fiscal deficit, as percentages of GDP, are projected at -2.3 per cent and 3.2 per cent respectively

data.headline: Indian economy likely to grow at 7-7.4 per cent in FY19: NCAER
data.articleBody: New Delhi: Indian economy is projected to grow at 77.4 per cent in the current fiscal, economic policy think-tank NCAER said on Thursday.According to a report by the National Council of Applied Economic Research (NCAER), the real agriculture Gross Value Added (GVA) is envisaged to grow at 3 per cent and real industry GVA at 7 per cent in 2018-19."The forecast for Gross Value Added (GVA) at basic prices is 7.07.4 per cent. These forecasts at constant (201112) prices are based on NCAER's annual GDP macro model," NCAER's Mid-Year Review of the Economy said.GDP growth rate at market prices estimated at 7.47.7 per cent for 201819, the report said.The growth rates of exports and imports, in dollar terms, are estimated at 11.8 per cent and 16.9 per cent respectively.The current account balance and central fiscal deficit, as percentages of GDP, are projected at -2.3 per cent and 3.2 per cent respectively.NCAER said its estimates suggest that the combined output of kharif and rabi foodgrains during the current year may be in the region of 290 million tonnes, which is slightly higher than last year's record output.As per the report, the outlook for the Indian industrial sector remains mixed for current fiscal.Noting that after showing an uptick in the last quarter, almost all inflation metrics exhibited a decreasing trend, NCAER said," This was largely due to the deflationary trend exhibited in food prices. Inflation is expected to fall further in the next quarter due to moderating fuel prices." The NCAER also pointed out that the softening of headline CPI inflation in October 2018 and slump in global crude oil prices along with the pullback of the rupee in November 2018, reduce the chance of a rate hike at the RBI's bimonthly monetary policy meeting to be held on December 5, 2018.
keywords: National Council Of Applied Economic Research
data.description: The current account balance and central fiscal deficit, as percentages of GDP, are projected at -2.3 per cent and 3.2 per cent respectively

66879158.headline: Economists say GDP data suggests slower potential growth
66879158.summary: HDFC Bank said though the back-series does not show any directional change compared to the old series.

data.headline: Economists say GDP data suggests slower potential growth
data.articleBody:
Most rating agencies have highlighted the risk of high government debt to GDP at 68 per cent and high combined fiscal deficit as an impediment for India's rating upgrade. Experts believe that the government may not deviate from fiscal consolidation track although the glide path is likely to be extended for FY18 and FY19 at 3.4 per cent and 3.2 per cent of GDP, respectively. NEW DELHI: The revised gross domestic product (GDP) data for fiscal years 2005-12 that lowered growth under the previous Congress-led United Progressive Alliance, may have depressed India’s long-term potential growth even though there is no directional change in the growth trend, independent economists said.HDFC Bank said though the back-series does not show any directional change compared to the old series, the maximum growth rate the economy achieved since 2004-05 now stands at 8.5 per cent for 2010-11, lower than the 10.3 per cent figure estimated earlier. “This could suggest that the long-term potential growth rate for India might be lower than what was perceived earlier,” said Tushar Arora, senior economist at HDFC Bank.The back series adjusts GDP numbers for the period using new methodology with the base year as FY12 and has scaled back growth in the UPA years from the peak of 10.3 per cent in FY11to 8.5 per cent. The new series also highlights that the contribution of the services sector was overestimated earlier and has been revised down. As per Aditi Nayar, principal economist at ICRA, the back series of GDP data highlights the volatility of Indian economic growth, with intermittent peaks in the pace of growth followed by dips.
  
  
  
  
  











“This suggests that sustaining a growth in excess of 8 per cent over an extended period of time may pose a challenge, particularly in the absence of a secularly supportive global growth environment,” Nayar said. While there has been a minor change in GDP at current prices from FY05-FY11 (.`0.5 trillion to.`1.5 trillion), key ratios such as fiscal deficit/GDP or debt/GDP are calculated at current prices and hence, are unlikely to change significantly.“Barring FY08, annual GDP year-on-year growth trend hasn’t changed,” said Devendra Kumar Pant, chief economist, India Ratings and Research. Economists have also questioned the approach followed on the expenditure side of the GDP, terming it simplistic. They said the splicing method could have exaggerated the past numbers due to which investment ratios in the back-series are looking higher for the previous years.Back series data shows deceleration in investment rate from 39.8 per cent in FY11to 30.6 per cent in FY18 and decline in gross savings rate to 29.6 per cent in FY17 from 36.2 per cent in FY11. These are major economic challenges which Indian economy is currently facing, Pant said. Saugata Bhattacharya, chief economist at Axis Bank, said, “Directionally, the growth is same and only the levels are different. Moreover, an investment ratio of 30-35 per cent is ‘normal’ for the Indian economy.”About the difference between the GDP back series released by Central Statistics Office (CSO) and those released by the National Statistical Commission (NSC), an economist said the committee under NSC has used an approach that was an extrapolation exercise, whereas CSO’s approach is a mix of extrapolation and usage of new data resources at hand.
data.description: HDFC Bank said though the back-series does not show any directional change compared to the old series.

66878464.headline: New GDP series better reflection of economy: Arun Jaitley
66878464.summary: A political slugfest erupted shortly after the Central Statistical Organisation (CSO) unveiled data on the back series of GDP, which showed a downward revision in growth rates during the UPA era

data.headline: New GDP series better reflection of economy: Arun Jaitley
data.articleBody: NEW DELHI: Finance minister Arun Jaitley launched a strong defence of the new GDP series on Thursday saying it was a better reflection of the Indian economy and globally more comparable. A political slugfest erupted shortly after the Central Statistical Organisation (CSO) unveiled data on the back series of GDP, which showed a downward revision in growth rates during the UPA era."Most experts, including those who have headed the CSO, have opined that this better represents the real state of the Indian economy. Obviously, when the new series is in place, it has to be used as a basis for backward revision," Jaitley said in a Facebook post.The FM also backed the CSO. "The CSO under various governments has always functioned objectively. It maintains an arms length distance from the finance ministry. North Block becomes aware of the final figures only when they are released. It is an organisation that has global credibility," he said.The FM said the CSO changed the method of calculating GDP in 2015. GDP growth rate estimates were revised from 2012-13 onwards with 2011-12 being the base year. Since then, every quarter and annually, GDP data is released on that basis.Jaitley said the immediate impact of the revision based on the new GDP series was on the last two years of the UPA government. For the year 2012-13, the growth rate was revised from 4.7% to 5.1% and later again to 5.5%. The Congress Party's reaction is given by those who perhaps have a nodding acquaintance with the subject. Data based on facts and on the best global practices is rejected by the Party because it takes away the last of its surviving arguments "my GDP growth was higher than yours", the FM said.He said sooner the Congress Party realises that its policy paralysis pushed India into the fragile 5 (group of five countries), the better it will be for the Party and its leadership.
data.description: A political slugfest erupted shortly after the Central Statistical Organisation (CSO) unveiled data on the back series of GDP, which showed a downward revision in growth rates during the UPA era

66878072.headline: Nifty, Sensex hit near two-month high ahead of GDP data, G20 meet
66878072.summary: Broader Asian markets wavered as investors remained cautious ahead of a crucial meeting between the Chinese and US presidents at the G20 meet

data.headline: Nifty, Sensex hit near two-month high ahead of GDP data, G20 meet
data.articleBody: New Delhi: Indian shares inched up on Friday, with both the indexes marking their highest level in nearly two months, while the Indian rupee strengthened to a fresh 3-month high ahead of key economic growth data later in the day. Broader Asian markets wavered as investors remained cautious ahead of a crucial meeting between the Chinese and US presidents at the G20 meet during the weekend that could determine the course of a heated trade war over the next year.  MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan wobbled between positive and negative territory in early trade and was last up 0.4 per cent. Back home, investors were awaiting gross domestic product data which probably moderated to 7.4 per cent in the July-September quarter, according to a Reuters poll, weakening just as Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government gets set for an election due by May. The data is expected by 1200 GMT. The Indian rupee gained up to 0.35 per cent on the day to 69.595 per dollar, its best since Aug 21. The broader NSE Nifty was up 0.25 per cent at 10,885.45 as of 0608 GMT, while the benchmark BSE Sensex rose 0.27 per cent to 36,268.19. The broader NSE index breached its 10,900 level for the first time since Oct. 3, while the BSE index also clocked its best level in almost two months. "Decline in international crude oil prices and strengthening of rupee are the positives today," said R.K. Gupta, managing director at Taurus Asset Management, adding that we may see some profit booking in the second-half after Thursday's rally in some specific stocks. "Investors are also eyeing outcome of the G20 meet over the weekend," he said. Shares of Indian non-banking financial companies gained after the central bank relaxed rules to sell or securitise their loan books, in a bid to ease persistent stress in the sector. Dewan Housing Finance Corp Ltd's stock rose as much as 7.4 per cent, while those of Bajaj Finance Ltd gained up to 2.3 per cent, their highest since Sept. 19. IT firms were among the top performers on the Nifty, with Infosys Ltd up as much as 1.7 per cent. Meanwhile, shares in Tata Motors Ltd dropped as much as 3.9 per cent after its British unit Jaguar Land Rover said on Thursday it is going to cut 500 jobs temporarily at its plant in central England.
data.description: Broader Asian markets wavered as investors remained cautious ahead of a crucial meeting between the Chinese and US presidents at the G20 meet

66862683.headline: Arun Jaitley to present interim budget on February 1
66862683.summary: This will be the sixth consecutive Budget to be presented by Jaitley.

data.headline: Arun Jaitley to present interim budget on February 1
data.articleBody: NEW DELHI: Finance minister Arun Jaitley will present the interim budget for 2019-20 fiscal on February 1, 2019.The finance ministry Wednesday said "the work for preparation of interim Budget 2019-20 has already commenced and is now gaining momentum".It has already sought inputs from different central ministries for the budget speech, which would be the last budget of the current BJP-led NDA government before the 2019 general polls.Last month, the ministry began the budgetary exercise for 2019-20. During the process, meetings were held with the ministries of steel, power, and housing and urban development, among others, to finalise revised expenditure for the current fiscal and projections for the next financial year.The ministry will impose quarantine from December 3, which will bar the entry of media persons into the North Block, the seat of the country's Finance Ministry, till the date of presentation of the interim Budget by the finance minister in Parliament on February 1, 2019, it said.This will be the sixth consecutive Budget to be presented by Jaitley.As per practice, a vote-on-account or approval for essential government spending for a limited period is taken in an election year and a full-fledged budget is presented by the new government.The Narendra Modi-led government scrapped the colonial-era tradition of presenting the budget at the end of February. With the preponement of budget, ministries are now allocated their budgeted funds from the start of the financial year beginning April.This gives government departments more leeway to spend as well as allow companies time to adapt to business and taxation plans.Previously, when the budget was presented at the end of February, the three-stage Parliament approval process used to get completed sometime in mid-May, weeks ahead of the onset of monsoon rains. This meant government departments would start spending on projects only from August-end or September after the monsoon season ended.
data.description: This will be the sixth consecutive Budget to be presented by Jaitley.

66862106.headline: Modi and Xi aim to build on thaw in ties at G20 meeting
66862106.summary: Modi's meeting with Xi at the G20 summit in Argentina will be their fourth this year, Indian Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale said

data.headline: Modi and Xi aim to build on thaw in ties at G20 meeting
data.articleBody: NEW DELHI: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Chinese President Xi Jinping will meet on the sidelines of a G20 meeting this week, aiming to build on a thaw in ties after a military standoff on their disputed border last year, officials said. The 3,500 km (2,200-mile) border between the nuclear-armed neighbours has been calm since Modi and Xi held several hours of talks in the Chinese city of Wuhan in April, agreeing to prevent political disputes escalating into confrontation. Later this year, their two armies will hold joint exercises in a bid to build trust after their 73-day face-off in a remote, high-altitude stretch of the Himalayan border that stoked fears of war. Modi's meeting with Xi at the G20 summit in Argentina will be their fourth this year, Indian Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale said. "It was decided that they would take the opportunity whenever and wherever they could meet. They could discuss issues on either leader's mind or issues of mutual concern," Gokhale told reporters. As well as long-standing disputes over their border, the two countries are vying for influence in the Indian Ocean and squabbling over Xi's signature Belt and Road infrastructure initiative. India has warmed up to the new government in the Maldives, offering financial help after it accused the previous government of striking secret deals with Chinese firms that have left the tiny country of 400,000 people in debt. India and China are also aligned with opposing sides embroiled in political turmoil in Sri Lanka. In Buenos Aires, the leaders of two of the world's fastest growing economies are expected to endorse efforts to liberalise their trade, Indian officials said.  Negotiators from the two countries held talks in New Delhi on Wednesday to try to prise open each other's farm markets.  China wants to export apples and dairy products and India is hoping to export skimmed milk products and buffalo meat, two Indian sources with direct knowledge of the matter said. India banned the import of Chinese apples in 2017 after finding pesticides, while China restricted imports of Indian buffalo meat because of concern over foot and mouth disease. Chinese Vice Minister Hu Wei and Indian Commerce Secretary Anup Wadhawan are leading the talks on the farm products as part of a broader trade package "India's primary interest is exporting skimmed milk products and for China it is apples," one of the officials told Reuters on condition of anonymity due to the sensitive nature of the discussions. Their bilateral trade reached $89.6 billion in 2017/18 with a deficit of $62.9 billion in China's favour.  Indian officials said that China, locked in a trade dispute with the United States, has been more flexible than before with regard to the possible opening up of its markets to Indian pharmaceutical products and IT services.
data.description: Modi's meeting with Xi at the G20 summit in Argentina will be their fourth this year, Indian Foreign Secretary Vijay Gokhale said

66861454.headline: Rupee breaches 70 level against dollar on dovish remarks from Fed's Powell
66861454.summary: Around 9:10 am, the domestic unit was trading 50 paise higher at 70.11 to the US dollar.

data.headline: Rupee breaches 70 level against dollar on dovish remarks from Fed's Powell
data.articleBody: New Ddelhi: Rupee jumped over 50 paise to reach a sub-70 level in Thursday’s trade as dollar weakened against major world currencies on overnight dovish remarks from US Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell.At 10.03 am, the rupee was trading at 69.95 against the greenback, up 0.93 per cent. This was the first time that the rupee breached the 70-mark since August this year.  The domestic currency strengthened after the Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell said the US interest rates were just below neutral. This was taken by globally as a signal that the rate hike cycle was nearing its end.The domestic currency also gained on recent ease in crude oil prices and hopes of some positive developments in the US-China trade ties in the upcoming G20 summit. Dollar index, which compares the movement of dollar against a basket of six major world currencies, fell edged 0.09 per cent lower at 96.58. Most Asian currencies edged higher against the dollar in the morning trade. The domestic currency, which has been among the worst performing Asian currency this year, has gained over 5 per cent so far this month.  The domestic currency had strengthened 17 paise to 70.62 on Wednesday.
data.description: Around 9:10 am, the domestic unit was trading 50 paise higher at 70.11 to the US dollar.

66858166.headline: GDP backseries data: Niti Aayog's role raises eyebrows
66858166.summary: “Involving Niti in the GDP story is strange. It gives out signals that CSO (Central Statistics Office) lacks capability while the Aayog has all the intellectual prowess,” said an economist.

data.headline: GDP backseries data: Niti Aayog's role raises eyebrows
data.articleBody:
NEW DELHI: Niti Aayog’s involvement in the release of the GDP backseries data has raised eyebrows, with some questioning its role.The data was released at a press conference by Niti Aayog vice-chairperson Rajiv Kumar and chief statistician Pravin Srivastava. “Now that Niti Aayog has done the hatchet job, it is time to wind up the utterly worthless body,” former finance minister P Chidambaram tweeted. Former chief statistician Pronab Sen also questioned the involvement of Niti Aayog.“Involving Niti in the GDP story is strange. It gives out signals that CSO (Central Statistics Office) lacks capability while the Aayog has all the intellectual prowess,” said an economist, who did not want to be identified. 
  



“The revised ‘New Series’ computed by the ministry of statistics/Niti Aayog has completely undermined the NSC (National Statistical Commission), the autonomous body for deciding data transparently,” Congress party spokesperson Randeep Singh Surjewala said.The chief statistician said the back series was compiled by CSO and it was just a joint press conference. A panel set up by National Statistical Commission had also calculated the back series that bumped up growth in the UPA era. The panel headed by Sudipto Mundle had, however, suggested that two other approaches also be used.
data.description: “Involving Niti in the GDP story is strange. It gives out signals that CSO (Central Statistics Office) lacks capability while the Aayog has all the intellectual prowess,” said an economist.

66850275.headline: India Inc foreign borrowings down 66% to $1.41 billion in October
66850275.summary: The domestic firms had borrowed USD 4.09 billion from overseas markets through external commercial borrowings (ECBs) as well as Foreign Currency Convertible Bonds (FCCBs) in October 2017.

data.headline: India Inc foreign borrowings down 66% to $1.41 billion in October
data.articleBody: MUMBAI: India Inc's foreign borrowings dipped nearly 66 per cent to $1.41 billion in October this year, Reserve Bank data showed Wednesday.The domestic firms had borrowed $4.09 billion from overseas markets through external commercial borrowings (ECBs) as well as Foreign Currency Convertible Bonds (FCCBs) in October 2017.Besides, there was additional borrowings of $314.99 million through rupee denominated bonds (RDBs) in the year-ago month.However, the borrowings through RDBs remained unchanged in October this year.Of the total borrowing amount in October, the Indian companies brought in $1.40 billion through automatic route and the rest of $8.54 million was by way of approval route.Among the major borrowers, HPCL-Mittal Energy Ltd raised $350 million for rupee expenditure; Oppo Mobiles India Pvt Ltd $250 million for import of capital goods; Ostro Kutch Wind $88.27 million for new project; ICICI Home Finance Company $75 million for on-lending.Bharti Airtel raised $100 million each for tenors of 5 years and 6 years for refinancing of earlier ECB and rupee expenditure respectively.Taiyo Nippon Sanso India Pvt Ltd ($8.54 million) was the only company to have raised money from approval route.
data.description: The domestic firms had borrowed USD 4.09 billion from overseas markets through external commercial borrowings (ECBs) as well as Foreign Currency Convertible Bonds (FCCBs) in October 2017.

66850482.headline: Government revises downwards GDP growth data during UPA regime
66850482.summary: As per the data released, the economy in 2010-11 grew by 8.5% and not 10.3% as estimated earlier.

data.headline: Government revises downwards GDP growth data during UPA regime
data.articleBody: NEW DELHI: The government Wednesday lowered the GDP growth rates for a majority of the previous 10 years of the UPA regime, saying the data has been recalibrated to reflect a more appropriate picture of the economy.The GDP growth rates for FY 2006-12 have been revised using new back series data, Chief Statistician Pravin Srivastava said at a press conference here.As per the data released by the Central Statistics Office (CSO), the economy in 2010-11 grew by 8.5 per cent and not 10.3 per cent estimated earlier.
data.description: As per the data released, the economy in 2010-11 grew by 8.5% and not 10.3% as estimated earlier.

66822577.headline: India Inc's CSR expenditure increased 11% to Rs 10,030 crore in FY18
66822577.summary: The top spenders in terms of absolute CSR expenditure were Reliance Industries, ONGC, Tata Consultancy Services, HDFC Bank, Indian Oil Corp, Infosys, ITC, NTPC, Tata Steel and Wipro.

data.headline: India Inc's CSR expenditure increased 11% to Rs 10,030 crore in FY18
data.articleBody: New Delhi: India Inc’s social spending crossed Rs 10,000 crore last year, led by Reliance Industries and Oil & Natural Gas Corporation.Spending on corporate social responsibility (CSR) projects increased 11 per cent to Rs 10,030 crore in 2017-18, according to an analysis of 1,080 of 1,795 companies listed on the National Stock Exchange by PRIME Database Group.“CSR expenditure by NSE-listed companies has grown at a healthy CAGR of 16 per cent over the last three years,” said Pranav Haldea, managing director of PRIME Database Group.The number of companies that spent on CSR increased to 1,016 (94 per cent of the companies analysed) in 2017-18 from 931 (92 per cent) in 2016-17. The top 10 companies together accounted for 36 per cent of the total spending on CSR.The top spenders in terms of absolute CSR expenditure were Reliance Industries, ONGC, Tata Consultancy Services, HDFC Bank, Indian Oil Corp, Infosys, ITC, NTPC, Tata Steel and Wipro.Overall, 560 companies, or 59 per cent, increased their spending from the previous year.However, contributions to two government focus areas fell.Spending on Swachh Bharat declined 10 per cent to Rs 521 crore, while funding for the Clean Ganga project dropped 47 per cent to Rs 80 crore, data showed. The highest contribution towards Swachh Bharat was in 2015-16, at Rs 1,009 crore.As in the previous year, education received the most funding (38 per cent of the total), followed by healthcare (25 per cent). Spending was small in areas such as reducing inequalities (2 per cent), national heritage (4 per cent), armed forces (1 per cent), sports (2 per cent) and the Prime Minister’s Relief Fund (2 per cent). However, in comparison to the previous year, these areas saw the highest percentage increase in spending, with the PM’s fund attracting the biggest rise of 139 per cent.Allocations as a proportion of the total under various schedules remained fairly constant over the previous year, said Haldea.
data.description: The top spenders in terms of absolute CSR expenditure were Reliance Industries, ONGC, Tata Consultancy Services, HDFC Bank, Indian Oil Corp, Infosys, ITC, NTPC, Tata Steel and Wipro.

66811594.headline: RBI and government do not have to agree on every single issue: Arun Jaitley
66811594.summary: In democracy, you are meant to disagree on several issues. Otherwise it is meaningless, says FM.

data.headline: RBI and government do not have to agree on every single issue: Arun Jaitley
data.articleBody:
In an exclusive interview with Times Now, Finance Minister Arun Jaitley says a difference in perspective does not mean an

    




    




    


 institutional failure. In a democracy, everybody need not agree at the same time on complex issues.Edited excerpts: On RBI vs Govt controversyI do not believe that the central bank and the finance ministry can agree on every issue. They need not disagree on every issue. But by a process of consultation and discussion at various levels, whatever we have done is to ensure that consultations take place. Let me put the record straight. Consultations have taken place at the level of the prime minister on several occasions. They have taken place at my level on innumerable occasions. They take place at the level of the secretaries on several occasions.Let me just define the elements – there are some issues which are completely in the domain of the government; some issues are completely in the domain of the central bank. There is no dispute. Ultimately after consultation, you exercise your respective functions. In some areas, the policy is laid down by the government. Certain measures have to be taken by the central bank. There has to be a coordination between the two. Therefore, a difference in perspective does not mean that it is an institutional failure. In a democracy on complex issues, everybody need not agree at the same time.On Raghuram Rajan who was picked by the UPA governmentArun Jaitley: Not in the least. I have maintained utmost courtesies with the institution as also with the individuals who have manned these institution.But he resigned. Arun Jaitley: You are again factually wrong. He had a three-year term. He completed his three-year term. Your colleagues in the media made it out as though he has resigned. He did not resign. He completed his three-year term. On Urjit Patel, a man NDA government selected. You may not be on the same page with your co-anchors or colleagues on but that does not mean the institution has collapsed. In democracy, you are meant to disagree on several issues. Otherwise, it will become meaningless. Now the government’s view point is -- we respect and we will always maintain the autonomy within the framework of the laws which have been laid down. At the same time, if there are sectors of the economy which are starved of either liquidity or credit, as a sovereign government which represents the people and which has the larger interest of the economy in mind, we certainly will flag those issues. The common man feels the government wants RBI’s Rs 3.6 lakh crore reserves for financing the election year expenditure. Who has said this? It can be said only by those who took India’s fiscal deficit to 6% when they had the responsibility. We have nothing of this sort in mind. Let us first tell your so-called common man as to what fiscal deficit is. How much does the government collect and how much does the government spend. If you spend beyond your earnings, that is your fiscal deficit because you are borrowing from the markets. You are then going to leave your next generation in debt. During the UPA, it went haywire and went as high as 6%. We inherited a 4.6% fiscal deficit. This government since 1947 in its five-year tenure has the best record of fiscal prudence that any government has had.
data.description: In democracy, you are meant to disagree on several issues. Otherwise it is meaningless, says FM.

66811491.headline: Second quarter GDP growth likely to slow to 7.5-7.6 per cent: Report
66811491.summary: The GDP growth at constant prices (2011-12) was 8.2 per cent in the April-June quarter of 2018-19.

data.headline: Second quarter GDP growth likely to slow to 7.5-7.6 per cent: Report
data.articleBody: NEW DELHI: The GDP growth in the September quarter is expected to decelerate to 7.5-7.6 per cent over the previous three-month period mainly due to slowdown in rural demand, an SBI research report said Monday.The GDP growth at constant prices (2011-12) was 8.2 per cent in the April-June quarter of 2018-19.The Central Statistics Office (CSO) will be releasing the estimates for GDP growth for July-September on Friday.The 'SBI Ecowrap' report said the SBI Composite Leading Indicator (CLI), a basket of 21 leading indicators for September quarter of the current fiscal, is showing a marginal declining trend.Consequently, the headline second quarter Gross Value Added (GVA) growth could be 7.3-7.4 per cent, due to the slowing of rural demand, it said."We also believe that the growth numbers in the second quarter will be helped by a weak base in September quarter 2017-18."We estimate that the base impact on second quarter GVA growth is around 30 bps. Based on tax collections, we subsequently expect second quarter GDP growth at 7.5-7.6 per cent," said Ecowrap.It further said commercial vehicle sales, domestic air passenger traffic and cement production have maintained double-digit growth during July-September quarter. All these indicators pushed up GVA in the quarter.The monthly data of various indicators for October 2018 however suggest the GVA growth is slowing down due to decline in demand, the report said."Of particular concern, is that non-food credit, bank deposits and sale of passenger and commercial vehicles have slowed down as compared to previous month," it said.Also with a slowdown in government spending in the second quarter , the fiscal impulses to growth would now be clearly missing, the report added.
data.description: The GDP growth at constant prices (2011-12) was 8.2 per cent in the April-June quarter of 2018-19.

66811379.headline: India-China amends double taxation avoidance treaty
66811379.summary: Besides minimum standards, the Protocol brings in changes as per BEPS Action reports as agreed upon by the two sides, the ministry added.

data.headline: India-China amends double taxation avoidance treaty
data.articleBody: NEW DELHI: India and China have amended the bilateral tax treaty which will help prevent tax evasion by allowing the exchange of information, the Finance Ministry said Monday.The Government of India and the People's Republic of China have signed a protocol on 26 November, 2018, to amend the Double Taxation Avoidance Agreement (DTAA) for the avoidance of double taxation and for the prevention of fiscal evasion with respect to taxes on income."The Protocol updates the existing provisions for exchange of information to the latest international standards," the ministry said in a statement.Further, the Protocol incorporates changes required to implement treaty related minimum standards under the Action reports of Base Erosion & Profit Shifting (BEPS) Project.Besides minimum standards, the Protocol brings in changes as per BEPS Action reports as agreed upon by the two sides, the ministry added.Under Section 90 of the Income-tax Act, 1961, India can enter into an agreement with a foreign country or specified territory for the avoidance of double taxation of income, for the exchange of information for the prevention of evasion.
data.description: Besides minimum standards, the Protocol brings in changes as per BEPS Action reports as agreed upon by the two sides, the ministry added.

66810021.headline: RBI can transfer Rs 1 trillion of excess reserves to government: Report
66810021.summary: Additional forms of transfers can include Rs 1.16 trillion from the contingency reserves if one restricts to yield rise of 4.5 percent as against 9 percent at present.

data.headline: RBI can transfer Rs 1 trillion of excess reserves to government: Report
data.articleBody: MUMBAI: The Reserve Bank has "more than adequate" reserves and that it can transfer over Rs 1 trillion to the government after a specially constituted panel identifies the "excess capital", says a report.An RBI board meeting had last Monday decided to form a committee, which is likely to be announced later this week.ALSO READ: Government may raise PCA issue again if norms not eased by RBI"We expect the proposed committee on the RBI's economic capital framework (ECF) to identify Rs 1-3 trillion which is 0.5-1.6 per cent of GDP as excess capital," analysts at Bank of America Merrill Lynch said in a note Monday.The brokerage report said as per its stress tests, the central bank can transfer Rs 1 trillion to the government if the transfer is limited to passing excess contingency reserve and can go up to Rs 3 trillion if the total capital is included.Giving a break-up, the report said Rs 1.05 trillion can be transferred if the contingency reserve is capped at 3.5 percent of the RBI book. It further said this level will be 75 percent higher than the average of BRICS economies, excluding India.ALSO READ: RBI may hold the rates baton till March: ReportAdditional forms of transfers can include Rs 1.16 trillion from the contingency reserves if one restricts to yield rise of 4.5 percent as against 9 percent at present.Limiting the appreciation cover in RBI's currency and gold revaluation account to 25 percent (Rs 53.25 per USD) will release about Rs 72,000 crore to the government, it said.It also said capping the overall reserves at 20 percent of the RBI's book as against 28.3 percent now and higher than 18 percent recommended by the Usha Thorat panel will be able to release Rs 3.11 trillion.The statutes do not prohibit transfer of excess capital to the government, it said, pointing out that the RBI Act places no bar as long as government maintains Rs 5 crore of reserve funds under Sec 46 of the RBI Act.While Section 47 enjoins the RBI to credit its annual surplus to the national exchequer, after provisions, it does not place any restrictions on further transfers, it added.The RBI's contingency reserves at 7 percent are higher than the BRICS (excluding India) average of 2 percent, it said, adding the revaluation reserves are also on the higher side relative to BRICS central banks.As per a press statement after the nine-hour marathon board meeting, the government and RBI will be jointly deciding on the panel constitution and also its terms of reference.Following widespread criticism from many quarters, finance minister Arun Jaitley had said over the weekend that government did not need any support from the RBI's reserves for the next six months. However, multiple reports had claimed that the government is eyeing the extra cash which will help it in the run-up to the elections.This comes amidst falling GST collections and little borrowing window left for the government, as it has already used up close to 96 percent of borrowings as of end October. By taking the money from the RBI, the government will only increase its fiscal deficit, as it will have to issue bonds to the central bank.The government for the second year in a row has pegged fiscal deficit at 3.3 per cent of GDP this fiscal year. Many analysts are expecting government to overshoot this by at least 20-30 bps by March.
data.description: Additional forms of transfers can include Rs 1.16 trillion from the contingency reserves if one restricts to yield rise of 4.5 percent as against 9 percent at present.

66805361.headline: Despite India's fast-growing economy, many live below poverty line: NGT chairman
66805361.summary: We have people who are deprived of food ... there are people who are deprived of shelter and clothes, Justice Goel said

data.headline: Despite India's fast-growing economy, many live below poverty line: NGT chairman
data.articleBody: New Delhi: National Green Tribunal chairman Justice Adarsh Kumar Goel Sunday said India has earned its pride of place in the world with its economy growing "very fast" but a large number of people still live below the poverty line. The country had no doubt achieved growth but it was not "enough" to meet the aspirations of the freedom fighters who had drafted the Constitution, the NGT chairman regretted while speaking at a function at the Raj Bhavan here on the eve of Constitution Day. "Our economy is growing very fast, we have a place of pride in the world as a nation. But we have a large umber of people below the poverty line. We have people who are deprived of food ... there are people who are deprived of shelter and clothes," Justice Goel said.  He said, in many districts of Odisha, there are people who do not have sufficient clothes to cover their body. They use only one piece of cloth to cover their body even after 70 years of independence.  Stating that legislators, administrators, politicians judges, and lawyers are committed to ensure that justice is served, he said, "Justice means we must guarantee minimum need to all." Assam governor Jagdish Mukhi said the Indian Constitution is a fine blend of securing its peoples fundamental rights and realisation of the aspirations of the people in the directive principles. "We have a Constitution that is robust, comprehensive, stable and dynamic enough to realise the aspirations of our people." Speaking on the history of the Constitution, Vice Chancellor of National Law University and Judicial Academy, Assam, Dr J S Patil said the Constituent Assembly had adopted the Constitution of India on November 26, 1949 and it came into force later on January 26, 1950.
data.description: We have people who are deprived of food ... there are people who are deprived of shelter and clothes, Justice Goel said

66805240.headline: India eyes bigger share in global trade amid US-China tensions
66805240.summary: The trade war between the US and China may have a positive impact on India

data.headline: India eyes bigger share in global trade amid US-China tensions
data.articleBody: New Delhi: India will focus on boosting its exports to the US and other global markets as Chinese shipments become unattractive amid a trade war between the world’s biggest economies, the country’s trade minister said.New Delhi is focusing on a handful of items including automotive parts, chemicals, electrical equipment, among others, after the US and China slapped reciprocal duties on each other’s goods, minister Suresh Prabhu said in an interview. India’s share in global merchandise exports is at 1.7 per cent compared to China’s 12.8 per cent.“The ongoing trade tensions between the US and China may have positive impact," Prabhu said in a written reply to questions. “The long term strategy is to focus on enhancing manufacturing capabilities with focus not only on the United States but also keeping in view the demands in other markets, as well.”With President Donald Trump expected to go ahead with another round of tariffs on $200 billion of imports from China in January, India looks to gain from opportunities from the dispute. Southeast Asia, a region that’s mastered export competitiveness, is already seeing a boom in foreign direct investment as the trade war prompts companies to shift production to the region.Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s administration has been exploring ways to close the gap between exports and imports which reached $17.1 billion in October. The government has imposed some import curbs to ease pressure on the current-account deficit, a key vulnerability for the economy and one of the reasons why the rupee has lost more than 11 per cent against the dollar this year.The rising tensions could derail established trade orders like the World Trade Organization and will hurt smaller nations, Prabhu said.“This is not a welcome development for sustaining a free and fair trade,” he said.
data.description: The trade war between the US and China may have a positive impact on India

66803420.headline: NBFCs need enough liquidity for normal growth: S C Garg, Economic Affairs Secy
66803420.summary: The bank recapitalisation requirement may undergo a change if the yields get reduced further; mark-to-market provision may come down, said Garg.

data.headline: NBFCs need enough liquidity for normal growth: S C Garg, Economic Affairs Secy
data.articleBody: New Delhi: The government feels more needs to be done on liquidity to ensure NBFCs can start lending. In an interview to ET, department of economic affairs secretary Subhash Chandra Garg tells ET government will meet its fiscal deficit target and RBI’s governance structure needs to be reviewed. Edited excerpts from an interview with Deepshikha Sikarwar & Vinay Pandey.The rupee and oil have both reversed. Are you treating this as temporary, or is the problem behind us?Oil is a very special commodity. A 2% shortfall in supply in comparison to demand or 2% supply being in excess of demand can make the prices go haywire one way or the other. At some stage, I thought it would reverse and might go to less than $60 (to a barrel). It has reversed very fast and gone to about $63-64. That has an impact on our current account, the easing of concern on the rupee account has an impact on the behaviour of FPIs (foreign portfolio investors) and others. In October, there was a large withdrawal of money from India. Now you have seen them coming back. So the fundamental situation has changed. We would like to believe that this has changed for good… but oil being oil, you can never be certain, so you can’t take it as a permanent reversal kind of thing. At this moment, we should keep watch, see how durable this reversal is and then take additional decisions.Has it created a situation where excise duty cuts can be reversed because states, which levy taxes on fuel on an ad valorem basis, were also asked to undertake cuts.We don’t want to get into that kind of mindset. We need to watch for some more time. The relief on Iranian oil is said to be for six months. I think we should watch for some time more to see whether there should be any policy reversal.There is some concern about the fiscal deficit. There have been some murmurs about spending cuts...I don’t think anybody has been asked to cut expenditure that would have been approved for them. It is usual (that) most of the ministries and departments ask for additional funds. During the budget finalisation consultation (BFC) process, all these things are discussed and then a fair amount is allocated, which may even be larger than the one (sought). Only in those cases where the ministry’s implementation of the programme is such that there is virtually no likelihood of the entire allocated funds being utilised, then in RE (revised estimates) allocations are proposed to be reduced. But there is no such situation that we have to reduce allocations because we don’t have enough revenue streams. There is no forced reduction at all.What does that mean for the fiscal deficit?We are completely on track. We will achieve 3.2% (of GDP). The BFC is also done for the next year. As per our medium-term fiscal framework, next year we are supposed to go up to 3.1%. We hope to do better than that.You said India is fiscally comfortable, so how is the bank recapitalisation plan working out?We are comfortable. I won’t say we are excessively comfortable. For bank capitalisation, we have Rs 65,000 crore provisioned for this year. Part of that has been used. The capitalisation requirement might also undergo a change if the yields get further reduced. The mark-to-market provision might come down. There are very positive signals on the IBC (Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code) process. So you keep on assessing the capital requirement. There is some work which is being done that there might be some additional thing but I think more recent developments would need to be taken into account.So, there will be a fresh assessment?Yes.There are reports about the telecom sector staring at a default, so will North Block press for a spectrum auction?We have not seen any evidence of defaults so far. Two, for spectrum auction, there is a policy in place. What should be auctioned, what should not--that discussion is going on. There are certain issues about fixing a reasonable reserve price. Those are also being taken. As soon as it is ready, the auctions will be conducted.There is a suggestion from DoT on a reverse auction. Is that something that would acceptable?What you try to achieve is the best mode of auction which gives you the best price, keeping in consideration that we now have the new digital communication policy in place which also lays down different interests that it should serve. Balancing those interests, whatever should be the best mode of auctioning should be used.The telecom industry is also looking at some sort of relief package – moratorium on payments, as also staggered payments.This subject was examined by a subcommittee sometime back. Its findings were approved and payments due over 10 years were rescheduled to 16 years.Now the telecom industry is said to be seeking 18 years...The maximum licensing period is about 20 years. Last time also when it was done, it was done on a discounted basis in a manner that there is no net adverse impact on the government. I think a view would be taken, but whatever view is taken, no fiscal loss will be taken.There is some concern that liquidity constraints may hit growth. Moody’s has flagged this. Do you think the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has done enough or more steps are needed?In the latter part of September and October, some of the NBFCs (nonbanking finance companies) faced a liquidity crunch. They were not able to get their papers rolled over, there were rising interest rates etc. Our sense is that the liquidity situation in terms of the solvency aspect of it that some NBFCs might fall or that kind of situation--I think that is not there at all now with the liquidity situation also improving to some extent, measures taken by the government, RBI and all. But growth in this space was very high, in some cases even exceeding 40-50% a year. They were funding consumption expenditure, they were funding infrastructure financing, they were also funding housing, other real estate – lot of areas were basically funded by these NBFCs. Their flow of funds has certainly got reduced.First, they were trying to remain solvent. Second, now they are trying to refinance themselves with better asset-liability management. Many of them have reduced disbursements and they are not taking new exposure. This situation still requires support of liquidity and I think we need to continue to help manage the economy in such a way, the financial system in such a way, that they do get enough liquidity for at least their normal growth if not the extraordinary growth they were having. I hope we should be able to ensure this working with the Reserve Bank.You are saying some liquidity is required for growth?Yes, that is correct. Otherwise there would be some adverse impact.The RBI-government relationship has been in focus in recent times. Can we now say all is well? Are you satisfied with the outcome at the last board meeting on November 19?The Reserve Bank is an extremely important institution for the financial and economic management of the country. The government and the Reserve Bank have to work together to steer the economy to higher growth. The relationship between the government and the Reserve Bank is also quite multidimensional if I can put it that way. In my department itself, we must be on average writing something like two to three letters a day on different aspects. We interact on financial markets, currency, foreign exchange management and several other aspects. There is a very detailed, comprehensive, consultative interactive mechanism. Many times the media and analysts focus on the smaller part of the relationship--monetary management or reserve management.Second, the consultative mechanism between the two is also of a different colour and different dimension. For example, if I can give one instance, for foreign exchange management, the law says that for debt instruments, whether it is ECB (external commercial borrowings) or other kind of loans, borrowings, liabilities and guarantees etc., the regulations, rules will be made by the Reserve Bank of India in consultation with the government. For non-debt instruments, the law says the rules will be made by the government in consultation with the Reserve Bank of India. So, there are enormous ways and means by which consultation takes place.Monetary policy over the years rightly recognised that there may be some situations where the government might be running a fiscal policy in a manner which may not be may not be conducive to inflation management. Before 2016, it was the governor who was in charge of monetary policy. In 2016, the Act was amended. Now we have formed a monetary policy committee. But even there, the inflation target is legally set by the government. Then the Reserve Bank is supposed to achieve that.It is such an intricately constructed relationship that I don’t think anyone can say this is supreme, this is not supreme or this is independent, this is not so independent. Very carefully instruments have been created, something which is, let us say, very close to independence. To my mind, this means that the Reserve Bank can say or act against what the government is doing. Those situations can also arise sometimes. As I said, if you are running a fiscal policy in such a way that there is expansion of money, debt is expanding and things like that, then the Reserve Bank should have the instruments to control money supply even if the government doesn’t like it. The present context is not that at all.The government is running a fiscal policy in a manner which I think serves the purpose of inflation management. Who has done this kind of fiscal consolidation in our history for some time--deliberately planning and bringing down the fiscal deficit? But maybe there was a situation in 2008-09 or 2009-10 when we had also launched stimulus, inflation was 10% or 11%--maybe that was the situation where Reserve Bank could have exercised that independence of authority that is there. My sense is that let’s understand this relationship in its true sense. I don’t think we have any situation which can be problematic. It’s a situation which is going on, consultations are going on. The other aspect we should also see is that there is an evolution of the relationship or the evolution of the Reserve Bank of India itself. Those days, when we used to automatically monetise the deficit, the undersecretary here used to issue ad-hoc treasury bills, which would automatically lead to money expansion. All those days are gone. Several things have evolved, the governance structure was also evolving. The current structure of the committees etc. the Reserve Bank has was laid down in (19)49 and things like that. The way the world makes regulations has also changed. The complexity of the financial system, its integration globally has also changed. So, I think it’s legitimate to take stock of the situation and improve upon if that is functionally required.What really put the focus on the relationship was the never-used Section 7 being cited in communications between the government and the RBI. Deputy governor Viral Acharya’s October speech brought the tension into public view.I can say that that speech was bit unfortunate. By the way it (the government) did not use Section 7. Normally, the central banks use much more guarded language. There are also a lot of misgivings about this Section 7. In the architecture of the governance structure, there are three main players. One is the central government, another is the central board and the governor and the deputy governors. Section 7 essentially refers to the direction the government can give about the governance structure of the Reserve Bank. The way it is worded like this – “subject to the directions of the government, board of the directors of the central board…”Section 7 can also be used to do consultation like the various ways like I referred. Legal consultation of Fema (Foreign Exchange Management Act) is also a law-based consultation. In fact, the trigger came from somewhere else. There was a case in the Allahabad High Court and I am told it was even suggested by the Reserve Bank of India’s attorney there that Section 7 consultation can be used in the process. So, the court said that you carry out consultation under Section 7--so that is where it started. You set about consultation process on that, then some of these other issues also came up. There is nothing like nuclear option, as if some Bramhastra is being fired. It’s one of the ways of doing consultation and that’s all we have done.Earlier you said the situation has changed and so there needs to be a change in the way institutions function in terms of composition and the powers that committees, subcommittees, boards have. Is there a need for another look at these structures?There is the governance agenda, which is coming up for discussion at the December 14 RBI central board meeting. There are certain proposals to look at this precisely for the reasons that I explained earlier. I think jointly discussing, we should come up with something.What is the object behind seeking a review of the RBI’s capital framework? The impression is that the government wants Rs 3.6 lakh crore of Reserve Bank’s surplus.Sometimes imaginations run wild. At no stage, it (transfer of Rs 3.6 lakh crore surplus) has been proposed. I am not referring to the academic exercise that the chief economic advisor undertook and presented it as part of the Economic Survey--that’s a different exercise. He also brought up certain other things such as the universal basic income. That’s a separate exercise, it’s not a government proposal. The government has at no stage asked for transfer of any reserves or buffer. There has been no proposal at any point in time.The main significance of the economic capital framework of the Reserve Bank lies in deciding how much of the profits of each year the Reserve Bank transfers to the government. Statutorily, it has been provided for in Section 47 of the RBI Act, which says after you have made provisions for bad and doubtful debt, which the Reserve Bank does not have, make provisions for depreciation and for any other purpose you are required to make. And then there is one open-ended thing that that you should make provisions on the lines of what bankers normally do, which is prudential risk related.Once you have written that formula that how much capital would you need, then you compare with the amount of the capital you are holding. If the Reserve Bank is holding less capital than what the reserves require, then you should not distribute full profits, you retain a part. That’s the construct. It is not for the first time that the economic capital framework determination or this provision business is being done. We have had the V Subrahmanyam committee, we have had the Usha Thorat committee. The last look was done by YH Malegam in 2014. He at that time had come to the conclusion that the Reserve Bank is holding Rs 1.49 lakh crore extra. At that time, Malegam made a recommendation, which was accepted by the board, that for next three years you transfer 100% to the government. And, at the end of the three years we will see.The capital framework adopted in 2016 in our judgement adopted principles and formulae that were much more extreme than what in our judgement define the test of what normally bankers would hold. Therefore, we have been asking the Reserve Bank from the last one year or so that let’s have a review of the economic capital framework. This has now been agreed to and a committee will look into it very objectively.It will study the practices world over as to how other central banks do it and then come out with its own formulation. This time, to avoid (the perception) that it is unilateral or something there would be some representation of the government also and representation of the Reserve Bank. It would be headed by someone independent, someone eminent who knows the central bank and the government. Hopefully, it will be constituted very soon. Then it will take some time to come out with its recommendations and then those will be taken by the board.Will it be in place before the December 14 meeting?Certainly--both the finance minister and governor will decide and constitute it.There is a view in some quarters that the government does not have much say in the internal committees that will discuss issues such as the prompt corrective action (PCA) framework in which it has sought changes.Why should we pre-judge anything? If something has been agreed to be jointly referred to BFS (Banking Financial Supervision committee), let BFS do its business and it come to the board.Would the government seek reconstitution of the BFS committee?I would not like to specifically comment on any committee. As part of governance reforms, the larger institutional structure would be looked at.What is the status on the Payments Regulatory Board? The RBI has made its dissent on the committee’s recommendations public.I think some clarification is in order on it. There is a joint report of recommendations that the RBI has signed on to. That report describes the differences only on one essential aspect. There is no difference on the view that there should be an independent regulator on the payments side. In fact, a kind of independent regulator has already been created by way of amendment to the Finance Act--the Payments Regulatory Board. The essential difference was whether the head of the payments regulator or payments settlement board should be the governor himself or another person with central banking experience.Most people in the committee felt it should not be ex officio as it requires much more of attention, so should be full time. But the central banking experience is essential. So the committee recommended that the chairman should be someone with considerable central banking experience, but not the governor ex officio. The RBI representative said it should be the central bank governor and that has been noted in the report. What later on came up in dissent the note, it has some other first principles also that have been discussed. But those had been settled very well. There is no open discussion about that. We now have to consult everyone formally as it is a recommendation of a group. We have to have consultations with the law department and also the RBI. So we are processing it for consultations.There is some speculation about this year’s budget, whether it will be a full one or interim or interim-plus.The convention is that in the interim budget we present estimates for entire next year. There have been one or two exceptions, but for the last 50-60 years, this has been the standard practice. Full budget is presented when the new government takes over with full policy announcements and full taxation proposals. That’s my sense should happen this year. I have no other instructions at this moment.
data.description: The bank recapitalisation requirement may undergo a change if the yields get reduced further; mark-to-market provision may come down, said Garg.
